0-13.scene_title: Ishmael's Decision to Go to Sea
0-13.description: Ishmael explains his reasons for going to sea, driven by a need to escape the dreariness and routine of life on land.
text_phrases: little or no money in my purse

0-13.scene_title: Manhattoes and the Fascination with Water
0-13.description: Ishmael describes the city of Manhattoes surrounded by commerce and people drawn irresistibly towards the water.

0-13.scene_title: Ishmael's Reflections on Water and Meditation
0-13.description: Ishmael muses on the universal attraction to water and its deep connection with meditation and the human psyche.
text_phrases: dreamiest, shadiest, quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape
trees, each with a hollow trunk
up from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke

0-13.description: Ishmael details his experiences and reasons for repeatedly choosing to work as a sailor rather than traveling as a passenger or officer.
0-13.dialog_summary: Ishmael discusses the practical and philosophical reasons for his preference to work as a sailor.
text_phrases: go to sea as a simple sailor

14-30.description: Ishmael prepares for his whaling voyage by packing his belongings and heading towards Cape Horn and the Pacific, starting from New Bedford.
14-30.dialog_summary: Ishmael talks to himself about finding a place to stay and being cautious about the lodging prices.
text_phrases: stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag
started for Cape Horn and the Pacific
passed the sign of 'The Crossed Harpoons'
paused one moment to watch the broad glare in the street

14-30.description: Ishmael arrives at The Spouter Inn, a dimly lit, dilapidated inn, which he chooses for its cheap lodging and the promise of pea coffee.
14-30.dialog_summary: Ishmael contemplates the ominous names of the inn and its owner but decides to stay due to the affordability.
text_phrases: came to a dim sort of light not far from the docks
heard a forlorn creaking in the air
saw a swinging sign over the door
thought that here was the very spot for cheap lodgings

14-30.description: Inside The Spouter Inn, Ishmael observes a mysterious and heavily defaced oil painting that captivates his curiosity.
text_phrases: found yourself in a wide, low, straggling entry
hung a very large oil painting
throwing open the little window towards the back of the entry

31-58.description: The narrator describes entering a dimly lit public room of an inn, which resembles the cockpit of an old ship. The room features a long table with glass cases and a bar designed to mimic a whale's head.
text_phrases: long, low, shelf-like table covered with cracked glass cases
vast arched bone of the whale’s jaw

31-58.description: The narrator joins other seamen for a cold supper in an adjoining room, where they eat under dim candlelight, discussing their experiences and the peculiarities of their fellow mariner, the harpooneer.
31-58.location: Adjoining dining room of the inn
31-58.dialog_summary: The narrator inquires about the harpooneer and expresses his reluctance to share a bed with him. The landlord describes the harpooneer's eating habits humorously.
characters: young fellow in a green box coat
text_phrases: number of young seamen gathered about a table
examining by a dim light divers specimens of skrimshander
cold as Iceland—no fire at all

31-58.scene_title: Return to the Bar and Arrival of the Grampus's Crew
31-58.description: After supper, the company returns to the bar where they encounter a rowdy group of mariners from the Grampus, who have just landed and are seeking refreshments at the bar.
31-58.dialog_summary: The landlord identifies the noise as coming from the Grampus's crew and anticipates news from the Feegees. The mariners order drinks and share their ailments.
text_phrases: Jonah mixed him a pitch-like potion of gin and molasses

59-83.description: The scene involves a dialogue between the narrator and the landlord discussing the mysterious harpooneer who is out late trying to sell a peculiar item.
59-83.dialog_summary: The narrator is confused and irritated by the landlord's stories about the harpooneer selling his head. The landlord explains that the harpooneer is actually trying to sell a shrunken head from New Zealand, not his own head.

84-105.scene_title: The Ritual of the Congo Idol
84-105.description: The scene describes a mysterious and somewhat eerie ritual performed by Queequeg with a small wooden idol. He sets up the idol in the fireplace, offers it a biscuit after lighting a fire with shavings, and then extinguishes the fire and stores the idol back in his pocket.
84-105.location: In a room aboard the ship

84-105.description: In a tense and dark scene, Queequeg, after performing his ritual, suddenly turns off the light and jumps into bed with the narrator, wielding a tomahawk. The narrator is terrified and calls for help until the landlord arrives to calm the situation.
84-105.location: In a room aboard the ship
84-105.dialog_summary: The narrator is terrified and calls for help, mistaking Queequeg's actions as a threat. The landlord reassures the narrator that Queequeg means no harm.
text_phrases: flourishing about me in the dark
landlord came into the room light in hand

84-105.description: The morning after the unsettling night, the narrator wakes up to find Queequeg's arm affectionately thrown over him, leading to a moment of reflection and eventual understanding between the two.
84-105.location: In a room aboard the ship
text_phrases: tomahawk sleeping by the savage’s side

106-126.description: Queequeg dresses in a peculiar manner, starting with his hat, struggling with his boots under the bed, and using a harpoon to shave.
106-126.dialog_summary: The narrator observes and internally comments on Queequeg's unusual dressing habits, but there is no spoken dialogue.
text_phrases: staring at him from the bed
commenced dressing at top by donning his beaver hat
crush himself—boots in hand, and hat on—under the bed
emerged with his hat very much dented
began creaking and limping about the room
took up a piece of hard soap
takes the harpoon from the bed corner

106-126.description: Queequeg and the narrator join a breakfast with whalemen who are surprisingly shy and quiet despite their bold professions.
106-126.dialog_summary: The landlord announces breakfast, but the whalemen remain mostly silent, creating a curious contrast to their adventurous professions.
text_phrases: sat at a social breakfast table
reaching over the table with his harpoon
all wearing monkey jackets for morning gowns

127-146.description: Ishmael visits the Whaleman’s Chapel in New Bedford, observing the solemn atmosphere and the scattered congregation of sailors and their families. The chapel is adorned with marble tablets commemorating lost whalemen.
127-146.dialog_summary: No direct dialogue, but Ishmael reflects on the solemnity and significance of the chapel and the marble tablets.
text_phrases: shaggy jacket of the cloth called bearskin

127-146.description: Father Mapple enters the chapel during a storm, removes his wet outer garments, and ascends the pulpit using a side ladder designed like those used on ships. He then secures the ladder inside the pulpit, symbolizing his spiritual isolation.
127-146.dialog_summary: Father Mapple orders the congregation to condense, using nautical terms to direct them.
text_phrases: tarpaulin hat ran down with melting sleet

147-162.description: The preacher kneels in the pulpit, folds his hands, uplifts his eyes, and offers a deeply devout prayer, followed by reading a hymn with changing tones from solemn to exultant.
147-162.dialog_summary: The preacher reads a hymn with varying tones, expressing deep devotion and exultation.

147-162.description: Jonah, feeling guilty and trying to escape God's command, skulks around the wharves of Joppa, seeking a ship for Tarshish. He is mistaken for a criminal but eventually boards the ship after paying an inflated fare.
147-162.dialog_summary: Jonah interacts with the sailors and the captain, trying to secure passage on the ship. The captain scrutinizes him but eventually accepts his payment.
text_phrases: skulks about the wharves of Joppa
seeks a ship that’s bound for Tarshish
Jonah, on the mere suspicion of something wrong
Jonah sees this; but in vain he tries to look all ease and confidence
Jonah’s Captain prepares to test the length of Jonah’s purse

147-162.scene_title: Jonah's Turbulent Sleep and Storm at Sea
147-162.description: Jonah, having boarded the ship and paid his fare, tries to rest in his state-room. Meanwhile, a dreadful storm hits the ship, causing chaos on board while Jonah sleeps through the initial tumult.
147-162.dialog_summary: The captain and Jonah briefly converse about the journey and fare before Jonah attempts to rest.
text_phrases: Jonah throws himself into his berth
the ship casts off her cables
the uncheered ship for Tarshish, all careening, glides to sea

163-176.description: Sailors suspect Jonah's role in the tempest and cast lots to confirm their suspicions. Jonah's lot is chosen, leading to his confession and the decision to throw him into the sea.
163-176.location: On a ship during a tempest
163-176.dialog_summary: Sailors question Jonah about his identity and origins, leading to his confession of fearing the Lord and causing the tempest.
text_phrases: cast him forth into the sea

163-176.description: Jonah is thrown into the sea, which calms immediately as he is swallowed by a whale.
163-176.dialog_summary: Jonah prays from within the whale, accepting his punishment and leaving his deliverance to God.

163-176.description: A preacher passionately recounts the story of Jonah to his congregation, emphasizing repentance and the power of God's deliverance.
163-176.dialog_summary: The preacher uses Jonah's story to teach about repentance and the importance of facing one's duties and God's power.

163-176.description: Queequeg, alone at the Spouter-Inn, engages in his own rituals and reflects a serene contentment with his own company.
text_phrases: holding close up to his face that little negro idol

177-190.description: Ishmael and Queequeg share a quiet evening in a room, engaging in conversation, smoking together, and discussing various topics. The scene captures a deepening friendship and cultural exchange.
177-190.dialog_summary: Ishmael and Queequeg discuss the purpose of printing in a book, sights in the town, and share a social smoke. Queequeg offers Ishmael a puff from his pipe, and they exchange friendly gestures.

177-190.description: Ishmael and Queequeg solidify their friendship through a shared smoking session, leading to Queequeg declaring them as married in the sense of being close friends.
177-190.dialog_summary: After sharing a smoke, Queequeg expresses his affection for Ishmael by declaring them as married, meaning they are close friends. Ishmael contemplates the cultural differences and accepts the friendship.

177-190.description: Ishmael and Queequeg engage in a deep, personal conversation while sharing a bed, discussing their backgrounds and philosophies.
177-190.dialog_summary: Ishmael and Queequeg chat about their lives, beliefs, and the concept of worship, leading to Ishmael deciding to join Queequeg in his rituals.

191-209.description: Queequeg and the narrator borrow a wheelbarrow to transport their belongings to the ship, discussing Queequeg's affection for his own harpoon and sharing stories along the way.
191-209.location: Streets of Nantucket, near the wharf
191-209.dialog_summary: Queequeg explains why he prefers to carry his own harpoon and shares a humorous story about his first encounter with a wheelbarrow. The narrator and Queequeg also discuss cultural differences and customs.
text_phrases: adjust the sheath on his harpoon barbs

191-209.description: Queequeg and the narrator board the schooner 'Moss' and set sail from New Bedford, experiencing the lively atmosphere of the port and the open sea.
191-209.location: Acushnet river, departing from New Bedford
text_phrases: tossed the quick foam from her bows

191-209.description: During a chaotic moment on the schooner, Queequeg saves a young man from being swept overboard by skillfully trapping the swinging boom and later rescuing him from the water.
191-209.dialog_summary: The captain scolds Queequeg for nearly harming a man, but Queequeg dismisses the concern, emphasizing his focus on hunting large whales. Chaos ensues when the boom swings dangerously, leading to Queequeg's heroic actions.
text_phrases: darted from the side with a long living arc of a leap

210-231.description: The narrative describes the arrival of the characters in Nantucket after a fine sea journey, highlighting the unique and isolated geographical nature of Nantucket.
text_phrases: more lonely than the Eddystone lighthouse

210-231.description: The scene narrates the legendary story of how Nantucket was settled by the red-men, involving an eagle carrying off an infant which led the parents to discover the island.
text_phrases: borne out of sight over the wide waters

210-231.description: This scene describes the life of Nantucketers who, being born on a beach, naturally took to the sea, gradually advancing from catching crabs to exploring the world's oceans with a navy of ships.
text_phrases: waded out with nets for mackerel
launching a navy of great ships

210-231.description: Ishmael and Queequeg arrive at the Try Pots inn in Nantucket, where they encounter Mrs. Hussey and are offered a choice between clam or cod chowder.
210-231.dialog_summary: Mrs. Hussey and a man argue; she offers Ishmael and Queequeg a choice between clam or cod for supper.
text_phrases: little Moss came snugly to anchor

232-271.description: Queequeg places great confidence in Yojo's judgment regarding the selection of their whaling craft, despite the narrator's reservations.
text_phrases: Queequeg shut up with Yojo in our little bedroom
Yojo warming himself at his sacrificial fire of shavings

232-271.description: The narrator explores different ships and finally decides on the Pequod after examining its unique features and speaking with Captain Peleg.
232-271.dialog_summary: The narrator inquires about joining the crew of the Pequod and learns about Captain Ahab from Captain Peleg.
text_phrases: peered and pryed about the Devil-dam

232-271.description: The narrator encounters Captain Peleg under a makeshift tent on the Pequod and discusses his intentions to join the whaling voyage.
232-271.dialog_summary: The narrator expresses his desire to go whaling and see the world, and Captain Peleg quizzes him about his readiness and motives for whaling.

272-296.scene_title: Bildad and Peleg Discussing in the Cabin
272-296.description: In the cabin of the ship Pequod, Captain Peleg and Bildad are engaged in a heated discussion about the lay or share of the profits to be given to a new crew member. Bildad is reading from a large book, likely the Bible, and Peleg is trying to mend a pen. The atmosphere is tense as they debate the appropriate compensation, reflecting their differing perspectives on fairness and duty.
272-296.dialog_summary: Peleg and Bildad discuss the lay to be given to a new crew member, with Bildad suggesting a minimal amount and Peleg advocating for a more generous share. The conversation reflects their differing values and responsibilities towards the ship's owners and the crew.
text_phrases: mend a pen with his jack-knife
placed pen and ink before him
seated himself at a little table

297-324.description: Peleg angrily confronts Bildad, who calmly sits back down, unfazed by the outburst. Peleg also calms down and they resume their conversation about ship duties and Ishmael's friend who wants to join the crew.
297-324.dialog_summary: Peleg angrily confronts Bildad, who remains calm. They discuss ship duties and Ishmael's friend who wants to ship with them.
text_phrases: sat down again on the transom
sharpening a lance, mend that pen

297-324.description: Ishmael inquires about Captain Ahab and learns from Peleg about Ahab's enigmatic and intense nature, his past experiences, and his current mysterious condition.
297-324.dialog_summary: Peleg describes Captain Ahab's mysterious and intense nature, his academic and adventurous past, and hints at his physical and mental condition.
text_phrases: where Captain Ahab was to be found
fixed his fiery lance in mightier, stranger foes than whales

297-324.description: Ishmael becomes concerned for Queequeg's well-being after finding him unresponsive in his locked room, leading to a frantic situation with the landlady and the maid.
297-324.dialog_summary: Ishmael expresses concern for Queequeg's silence and unresponsiveness, leading to a frantic exchange with the landlady and the maid about what to do.
text_phrases: trying to force open the door
caught me as I was again trying to force open the door

325-358.description: The narrator tries to open a door by running into it, only to find Queequeg sitting motionless in the room, observing his Ramadan. Despite attempts to communicate and move him, Queequeg remains still until the next morning when he rises after the sun comes up.
325-358.dialog_summary: The narrator and the landlady attempt to communicate with Queequeg, who remains silent and motionless. The narrator tries to convince Queequeg to move and eat, but fails. Queequeg only speaks the next morning, stating his Ramadan is over.
text_phrases: holding Yojo on top of his head

325-358.description: The narrator and Queequeg head to board the Pequod. They encounter Captains Peleg and Bildad who question Queequeg's religious affiliations and his appearance, leading to a discussion about the inclusivity of religion.
325-358.dialog_summary: Captains Peleg and Bildad challenge Queequeg's qualifications to board the ship, questioning his cannibalistic background and religious affiliations. The narrator defends Queequeg, asserting his membership in a universal congregation.
text_phrases: walking down the end of the wharf
loudly hailed us from his wigwam
sticking his head from behind Peleg’s

359-406.description: Peleg and Bildad discuss with Queequeg and the narrator in the cabin of the ship about signing the ship's articles and Queequeg's ability to write. Bildad gives Queequeg a religious tract and expresses his concern for the crew's souls.
359-406.dialog_summary: Peleg and Bildad discuss the signing of the ship's articles with Queequeg and the narrator. Bildad gives Queequeg a religious tract and talks about his concern for the crew's souls.

359-406.description: After leaving the Pequod, the narrator and Queequeg encounter a mysterious and ragged man named Elijah, who hints ominously about Captain Ahab and the upcoming voyage.
359-406.dialog_summary: Elijah talks cryptically about Captain Ahab and the Pequod, hinting at dangers and secrets. The narrator and Queequeg are puzzled and decide to leave.
text_phrases: fixed bayonet of his pointed finger

407-454.scene_title: Preparation and Loading of the Pequod
407-454.description: The scene describes the bustling activity as the Pequod is being prepared for its voyage. Aunt Charity, Captain Bildad's sister, is actively involved in ensuring that all necessary items are on board. She brings various items like pickles, quills, and flannel to the ship.
407-454.dialog_summary: Aunt Charity is determined to ensure nothing is missing on the Pequod and brings various items on board.
text_phrases: the heaviest storage of the Pequod had been almost completed
a continual fetching and carrying on board of divers odds and ends of things

407-454.scene_title: Early Morning Departure and Encounter with Elijah
407-454.description: Ishmael and Queequeg head to the Pequod early in the morning and encounter Elijah, who cryptically questions and warns them. They board the ship to find it quiet and the crew preparing to set sail.
407-454.dialog_summary: Elijah cryptically questions Ishmael and Queequeg about their boarding and warns them vaguely. Ishmael dismisses him and they proceed to board the ship.
text_phrases: it was nearly six o’clock, but only grey imperfect misty dawn
There are some sailors running ahead there

407-454.description: Ishmael and Queequeg find the ship quiet and the crew slowly starting to stir. They go below deck and find a rigger asleep, discussing quietly among themselves.
407-454.dialog_summary: Ishmael and Queequeg converse quietly, trying not to disturb the sleeping rigger. They discuss the peculiar customs of Queequeg's homeland.
text_phrases: The profoundest slumber slept upon him

455-479.description: Captain Peleg energetically commands the crew of the Pequod, giving orders to move aft and prepare the ship for departure. Bildad oversees the pilot's duties at the bow.
455-479.dialog_summary: Peleg commands the crew to move aft and prepare the ship, while Bildad sings psalms and oversees the anchor.
text_phrases: Captain Peleg was now all alive
Man the capstan! Blood and thunder!—jump!
Bildad...actively engaged in looking over the bows
singing what seemed a dismal stave of psalmody

455-479.description: The Pequod sets sail on a cold Christmas day, leaving the port as Captain Bildad and Captain Peleg bid farewell to the crew and each other, expressing mixed emotions about the long journey ahead.
455-479.dialog_summary: Peleg and Bildad give final commands and farewells to the crew, expressing hopes and concerns for the voyage.
text_phrases: the anchor was up, the sails were set, and off we glided
the long rows of teeth on the bulwarks glistened in the moonlight

480-505.description: The narrator reflects on the significant global impact of whaling, mentioning how whale oil is used worldwide and how whalemen have been pioneers in exploring unknown parts of the world.
480-505.location: Narrator's location, possibly on a ship or at a port

480-505.description: The narrator describes Starbuck, the chief mate of the Pequod, highlighting his physical and mental characteristics, and his background as a Quaker from Nantucket.

506-519.description: Stubb, the second mate, praises Starbuck's careful nature in whaling, hinting at a deeper exploration of what being 'careful' means in their line of work.
506-519.location: On the deck of the Pequod
506-519.dialog_summary: Stubb comments on Starbuck's carefulness in the whaling business.

506-519.scene_title: Starbuck's Reflection on Courage and Whaling
506-519.description: Starbuck contemplates the practical necessity of courage in whaling, influenced by his past experiences and losses in the ocean.
Stubb, characterized by his easy-going nature and indifference to danger, handles his duties on the whale-boat with a relaxed demeanor, using his pipe as a constant companion.
506-519.location: On the whale-boat, part of the Pequod

506-519.description: Flask, the third mate, exhibits a personal vendetta against whales, viewing them as mere nuisances to be conquered without fear or reverence.
506-519.location: On the deck of the Pequod

520-530.description: Captain Ahab stands on the quarter-deck of the Pequod, revealing himself for the first time after days of seclusion. His presence is commanding and his appearance marked by a livid scar, adding to his grim demeanor.
520-530.dialog_summary: No dialogue is present, but the crew shows unease through gestures and expressions under Ahab's commanding presence.
text_phrases: Captain Ahab stood upon his quarter-deck
barbaric white leg upon which he partly stood
looking straight out beyond the ship’s ever-pitching prow

520-530.description: After his initial appearance, Captain Ahab becomes more visible daily, either standing in his pivot-hole, seated on an ivory stool, or walking the deck. His mood seems affected by the changing weather as the ship sails into warmer climates.

531-556.description: Ahab scolds Stubb harshly, calling him a dog and threatening to rid the world of him, which causes Stubb to retreat and contemplate his reaction.
531-556.location: On the deck of the Pequod
531-556.dialog_summary: Ahab scolds Stubb, calling him a dog and threatening him, which leads to Stubb retreating and considering whether to confront Ahab or pray for him.
text_phrases: Below to thy nightly grave; where such as ye sleep between shrouds
old man's hammock clothes all rumpled and tumbled
pillow a sort of frightful hot

531-556.description: Ahab, feeling unsettled by his pipe no longer soothing him, tosses it into the sea and paces the deck, reflecting on his troubled thoughts.
531-556.location: Weather side of the deck, Pequod
531-556.dialog_summary: Ahab reflects on how smoking no longer soothes him and decides to toss his pipe into the sea.
text_phrases: calling a sailor of the watch
lighting the pipe at the binnacle lamp
tossed the still lighted pipe into the sea

531-556.description: Stubb recounts a bizarre dream about Ahab and his ivory leg to Flask, who finds the dream somewhat foolish.
531-556.dialog_summary: Stubb tells Flask about his dream where Ahab kicks him with his ivory leg, leading to a surreal encounter with a merman. Flask responds skeptically.

stern was stuck full of marlinspikes

557-574.scene_title: Proclamation of the Sperm Whale's Reign
557-574.description: The scene describes a shift in cetological authority, where the sperm whale is declared the new monarch of the seas, replacing the Greenland whale.
text_phrases: the great sperm whale now reigneth

557-574.description: The narrator discusses the need for a comprehensive classification of whales and offers to take on the task, despite its challenges.
text_phrases: project the draught of a systematization of cetology

557-574.description: The narrator recounts a discussion with friends about whether whales should be classified as fish, referencing historical and scientific perspectives.
557-574.dialog_summary: Narrator discusses with Simeon Macey and Charley Coffin about Linnaeus's classification of whales, concluding that the reasons for excluding whales from fish are insufficient.
text_phrases: reasons set forth were altogether insufficient

557-574.description: The narrator provides a definition of a whale, emphasizing its unique characteristics compared to other fish.
text_phrases: a whale is a spouting fish with a horizontal tail
definition is the result of expanded meditation

557-574.description: The narrator outlines the structure of his cetological work, dividing whales into books and chapters based on their size and characteristics.

575-593.description: The narrator discusses the difficulty of classifying whales based on external features like baleen, humps, and fins, and suggests a more holistic approach.
Description of the Hump Back whale often seen on the northern American coast, noted for its playful nature and less valuable oil.

575-593.description: Brief mention of the elusive Razor Back whale seen off Cape Horn, known for its retiring nature and sharp ridge back.

Detailed description of the Narwhale, noted for its distinctive tusk used for breaking ice and its rarity.

575-593.description: Description of the Thrasher whale using its tail to thrash its enemies and how it maneuvers on the back of larger whales.

594-609.description: Dough-Boy, the steward, announces dinner to Captain Ahab who has been observing the sun. Ahab, after hearing the announcement, heads to the cabin without much reaction. Following this, the chain of dinner announcements continues among the officers until Flask turns the routine into a playful moment before entering the cabin.
594-609.location: On the deck of the Pequod
594-609.dialog_summary: Dough-Boy announces dinner to Ahab, who then informs Starbuck. Starbuck tells Stubb, and Stubb informs Flask. Each officer acknowledges the message before heading to the cabin.

taking an observation of the sun

a grave peep into the binnacle
tipping all sorts of knowing winks

610-619.description: Ahab presides over the dinner table with his officers around him, in a scene reminiscent of a solemn royal banquet. The officers, showing deference yet equality, focus intently on Ahab as he carves the beef, a moment of silent reverence and subtle social dynamics.
610-619.dialog_summary: Ahab silently serves the beef to his officers, who receive it with great circumspection and respect, maintaining a solemn silence throughout the meal.

610-619.description: After the officers' dinner, the harpooneers enjoy a raucous meal, filled with lively actions and a stark contrast to the earlier solemnity. The harpooneers, including Queequeg and Tashtego, display their hearty appetites and boisterous behavior, creating a lively and almost chaotic dining experience.
610-619.dialog_summary: The harpooneers dine with gusto, making loud noises as they eat, and occasionally engaging in playful yet rough behavior with Dough-Boy, the steward.

620-632.description: The scene describes the serene and meditative environment experienced by whalemen stationed at the mast-head of a whale ship. It contrasts the physical discomfort and lack of amenities with the mental and spiritual expansiveness afforded by the vast, open sea.
620-632.dialog_summary: A harpooneer chides a young lookout for not spotting any whales during their voyage, highlighting the lookout's meditative state and lack of attention to the task.

stand upon two thin parallel sticks called the t’ gallant cross-trees
carried aloft with you, in the shape of a watch-coat

633-674.description: Captain Ahab paces intensely on the deck of the ship, deeply absorbed in his thoughts, which seem to dictate his every movement. His stride leaves deeper marks on the deck, reflecting his inner turmoil.
Ahab halts his pacing to make a sudden call to gather all crew members aft. He stands by the bulwarks, inserting his bone leg into the auger-hole, and commands Starbuck to bring everyone on deck.
633-674.dialog_summary: Ahab orders Starbuck to gather all crew members aft, which surprises Starbuck due to the unusual nature of the command.
text_phrases: came to a halt by the bulwarks
inserting his bone leg into the auger-hole

633-674.scene_title: Ahab's Rallying Speech and the Gold Coin
633-674.description: Ahab addresses the gathered crew with fervor, asking them about their reactions to seeing a whale and their readiness to pursue it. He then dramatically offers a gold coin as a reward for spotting Moby Dick, nailing it to the mast.
633-674.dialog_summary: Ahab questions the crew's actions upon seeing a whale and their enthusiasm to hunt it down, culminating in offering a gold coin for spotting Moby Dick.
text_phrases: What do ye do when ye see a whale, men?
holding up a broad bright coin
nailing the gold to the mast

675-705.scene_title: Ahab's Command and the Ritual with the Crew
675-705.description: Captain Ahab receives a brimming pewter and commands the harpooneers and his mates to prepare for a ritual involving their weapons and a drink from a flagon. The crew forms a circle around Ahab as he initiates a drinking ritual, invoking a sense of unity and purpose among them.
675-705.location: On the deck of the Pequod
675-705.dialog_summary: Ahab orders the crew to drink from the flagon and pass it around, invoking a sense of ritual and camaraderie. He also commands the mates and harpooneers to prepare their weapons and positions.

675-705.scene_title: Ahab's Intense Interaction with His Mates
675-705.description: Ahab interacts intensely with his mates, grasping their crossed lances and attempting to impart his fiery emotion onto them. The scene captures a moment of high tension and mystical leadership as Ahab tries to unify his crew's resolve.
675-705.location: On the deck of the Pequod
675-705.dialog_summary: Ahab commands his mates to cross their lances and tries to transfer his intense emotions to them, but ultimately feels the effort might be in vain.
text_phrases: grasped the three level, radiating lances

675-705.description: Captain Ahab is alone in his cabin, reflecting deeply on his fate and destiny, expressing his tormented thoughts about his pursuit of Moby Dick and his own existential reflections.
675-705.dialog_summary: Ahab reflects on his relentless pursuit of Moby Dick, his physical and mental state, and his indomitable will to fulfill his prophecy of vengeance.

706-752.description: Various sailors engage in lively discussions and dancing aboard the ship, using playful and boisterous language. They encourage each other to dance and make merry, despite the impending storm.
706-752.location: On the deck of a whaling ship
706-752.dialog_summary: Sailors from different nationalities encourage each other to dance and enjoy the night, despite some expressing dissatisfaction with the ship's floor or missing elements like girls. They use instruments like a tambourine and engage in playful banter.

it’s too springy to my taste
pitching the tambourine up the scuttle
I wonder whether those jolly lads
the green navies and the green-skulled crews
this is worse than pulling after whales
The sky-born, high-tide Ganges turned to wind
the snow’s caps turn to jig it now
Hail, holy nakedness of our dancing girls
How the sea rolls swashing ’gainst the side
Blood! but that old man’s a grand old cove
A row! a row! a row
A row a’low, and a row aloft

753-768.scene_title: The Legendary Terror of Moby Dick
753-768.description: The scene describes the widespread fear and rumors surrounding Moby Dick, emphasizing his supernatural reputation among whalemen. It highlights the reluctance of even experienced whalemen to confront Moby Dick due to the terrifying tales associated with him.

753-768.scene_title: The Ubiquity and Immortality of Moby Dick
753-768.description: This scene explores the mythical beliefs about Moby Dick being omnipresent and immortal. It discusses the whale's ability to appear in different locations simultaneously and the superstitions of whalemen regarding Moby Dick's invincibility.

753-768.scene_title: Ahab's Vengeful Pursuit of Moby Dick
753-768.description: Captain Ahab's intense and personal vendetta against Moby Dick is depicted, stemming from the loss of his leg in a previous encounter with the whale. Ahab's obsession and the physical and psychological scars he bears fuel his relentless pursuit of the whale.
text_phrases: smote him with more seeming malice

769-782.description: Captain Ahab, with his ivory leg, steps ashore in Nantucket, hiding his deep, mad obsession with hunting the White Whale, Moby Dick. Despite his apparent grief, he is consumed by a secret rage and desire for revenge against the whale.
text_phrases: with ivory leg he stepped ashore
mad secret of his unabated rage

769-782.description: Ahab leads a diverse and morally questionable crew on the Pequod, including renegades and castaways, as they set out on a whaling voyage driven by Ahab's thirst for revenge against the White Whale.
text_phrases: crew, too, chiefly made up of mongrel renegades, and castaways

769-782.description: Ishmael reflects on the terrifying aspect of the White Whale, Moby Dick, and how the whiteness of various creatures and objects can evoke a profound sense of dread and horror.

783-803.description: The scene describes the capturing of an albatross using a treacherous hook and line while it floated on the sea. The captain then uses the bird to carry a lettered tally, marking the ship's time and place, before releasing it.
783-803.dialog_summary: The narrator contemplates the mystic nature of the albatross and its capture.

783-803.dialog_summary: The narrator questions and analyzes the peculiar and often terrifying impact of whiteness across different objects and legends.

804-828.description: Captain Ahab intensely studies sea charts in his cabin, tracing new courses and consulting old log-books to plan his hunt for Moby Dick.

829-841.dialog_summary: Ahab mutters to himself about having 'tallied' Moby Dick and questions whether the whale will escape him.

He acknowledges the need to use his crew effectively, understanding Starbuck's reluctance and planning to maintain the crew's focus away from the overwhelming goal.
857-877.dialog_summary: Ahab reflects internally, no direct dialogue.
text_phrases: consumed with the hot fire of his purpose

text_phrases: weaving what is called a sword-mat
using my own hand for the shuttle

857-877.description: A sudden whale sighting by Tashtego excites the crew of the Pequod, leading to immediate action to pursue the whale. The crew prepares the ship and boats for the chase.
857-877.dialog_summary: Tashtego spots a school of whales and alerts the crew, causing a flurry of activity.

878-907.description: Ahab commands the crew to lower the boats into the sea as they prepare to chase the whale. The crew, spurred by Ahab's thunderous voice, springs into action, leaping into the boats with practiced agility.

text_phrases: thick in our rear flew the inscrutable sea-ravens

949-967.description: Captain Ahab displays his grim determination and isolation as he commands the deck during a fierce storm, refusing to leave his post or seek shelter, while the crew struggles to maintain their positions against the crashing waves.
text_phrases: ivory leg inserted into its accustomed hole
crew driven from the forward part of the ship

949-967.description: The Pequod encounters another whaling ship, the Goney, in the vast ocean. A brief interaction occurs where Ahab inquires about the White Whale, highlighting the isolation and singular focus of his quest.

968-983.description: The text describes the sociable nature of whalers compared to other seafaring groups like merchant ships, men-of-war, slave ships, and pirates. It highlights the reserved interactions among different nationalities of whalers and the unique practice of 'Gam' among American whalers.
text_phrases: merchant ships crossing each other’s wake

968-983.scene_title: Definition and Practice of a Gam
968-983.description: The scene explains the concept of a 'Gam', a social meeting unique to whalers where they exchange visits by boat crews. It contrasts the simplicity and roughness of whaleboats with the more comfortable setups in other ships.
The Pequod encounters the Town-Ho, a homeward-bound whaleman ship with news of Moby Dick. This scene sets up a mysterious and ominous tone as it hints at a dark secret related to the white whale.
968-983.location: Near the Cape of Good Hope
968-983.dialog_summary: The crew of the Town-Ho shares news of Moby Dick with the Pequod's crew, hinting at a mysterious and possibly supernatural event involving the whale.

mincing knives down in the forecastle

1033-1065.description: The captain threatens the mutineers and punishes them by whipping, while one mutineer warns of murder if flogged. The scene escalates with threats and a near act of violence by the mate, which is halted by another hiss from a crew member.

1033-1065.dialog_summary: The captain threatens to mince the mutineers for the try-pots, punishes them with a rope, and a dialogue ensues where a mutineer threatens murder if flogged, and the captain and mate respond with threats of their own.

1862-1877.dialog_summary: Ahab commands the steersman about steering the ship and later orders the carpenter to make a new leg using the best ivory available.
text_phrases: ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock

1878-1915.description: The carpenter of the Pequod is depicted as a versatile and efficient worker, capable of handling various mechanical emergencies and tasks aboard the ship. He works at his vice-bench, a large table equipped with vices of different sizes, where he addresses various needs such as repairing boat parts, creating items from whale bone, and even medical remedies.
1878-1915.location: On board the Pequod, Carpenter's Workshop
text_phrases: inserting bull’s eyes in the deck
reforming the shape of clumsy-bladed oars

1878-1915.description: The carpenter uses his skills to address unique requests and problems on the ship, such as adjusting a belaying pin, creating a bird cage from whale bones, concocting a soothing lotion, painting oars, and even performing a tooth extraction using his tools.
1878-1915.location: On board the Pequod, Carpenter's Workshop
1878-1915.dialog_summary: Carpenter addresses various requests from the crew, including adjusting equipment and creating items.

1916-1944.scene_title: Ahab and Carpenter Discussing the Leg
1916-1944.description: Captain Ahab discusses with the carpenter about the progress of a leg being made, expressing his frustration and existential thoughts. The carpenter resumes his work while reflecting on Ahab's peculiar nature.
1916-1944.dialog_summary: Ahab asks how long until the leg is done, and upon receiving the answer, he expresses his philosophical frustrations. The carpenter, resuming his work, muses about Ahab's oddness as told by Stubb.
text_phrases: How long before the leg is done?
Bungle away at it then, and bring it to me
bear a hand there with those screws

1916-1944.scene_title: Ahab and Starbuck Discuss the Leaking Oil
1916-1944.description: In the cabin, Captain Ahab and Starbuck discuss the leaking oil in the ship's hold. Ahab dismisses Starbuck's concerns about the leak, prioritizing his quest over the practicalities of the ship's condition.
1916-1944.dialog_summary: Starbuck informs Ahab of the leaking oil and suggests fixing it, but Ahab dismisses the concern, leading to a tense exchange where Starbuck warns Ahab to beware of himself.
text_phrases: Captain Ahab mistakes; it is I
The oil in the hold is leaking, sir
Let it leak! I’m all aleak myself
Ahab seized a loaded musket from the rack

1916-1944.description: Queequeg falls ill with a fever while working in the hold of the ship, leading to a poignant reflection on life and mortality as he lies in his hammock.
text_phrases: crawling about amid that dampness and slime
caught a terrible chill which lapsed into a fever
lay in his hammock, close to the very sill of the door of death

1945-1964.description: Queequeg expresses his desire to be buried in a canoe-like coffin, similar to those he saw in Nantucket, rather than being buried at sea in a hammock. He finds the idea more congenial and in line with his cultural beliefs.
1945-1964.dialog_summary: Queequeg requests a canoe-like coffin, explaining his cultural reasons and discomfort with the usual sea burial.

1945-1964.description: The carpenter is instructed to build the coffin as per Queequeg's request. He takes measurements and begins the construction using old lumber from the Lackaday islands.
1945-1964.dialog_summary: The carpenter takes measurements and starts constructing the coffin.
text_phrases: coffin was recommended to be made

1945-1964.description: The carpenter completes the construction of Queequeg's coffin. Queequeg examines it and makes additional requests for items to be placed inside, including his harpoon and provisions.
1945-1964.dialog_summary: Queequeg reviews the completed coffin and requests additional items to be placed inside.

1945-1964.description: Pip, emotionally moved, approaches Queequeg, who is lying in his coffin, and asks him to carry out a personal errand if he reaches the Antilles.
1945-1964.dialog_summary: Pip emotionally asks Queequeg to look for another missing person named Pip in the Antilles and comfort him.
text_phrases: Pip, who had been slily hovering

1965-2000.description: The old blacksmith recounts his tragic past, where a burglar, metaphorically referred to as the Bottle Conjuror, destroys his happy life by introducing alcoholism into his home. This leads to the loss of his property and the death of his wife, leaving him and his children destitute.
1965-2000.dialog_summary: The blacksmith shares his sorrowful story with others, explaining how his life was ruined by alcoholism introduced by a burglar.
text_phrases: a desperate burglar slid into his happy home
embraced a youthful, daughter-like, loving wife
the blacksmith’s infants were rocked to slumber

1965-2000.description: Captain Ahab visits Perth, the blacksmith, to have a special harpoon made. The harpoon is intended for Moby Dick, the white whale. Ahab and Perth discuss the process of making the harpoon, involving the melting down of horse-shoe stubbs and the intense labor of forging.
1965-2000.dialog_summary: Ahab asks Perth to forge a powerful harpoon from horse-shoe stubbs, and they discuss the resilience of the materials and the blacksmith's ability to smooth out imperfections.
text_phrases: Perth was standing between his forge and anvil
carrying in his hand a small rusty-looking leathern bag
plunged it all hissing into the cask of water

2001-2032.description: The scene describes a tranquil moment on the ocean where the character feels a deep connection with the sea, comparing it to a flowery earth and experiencing a dream-like state of quietude.
text_phrases: tranquil beauty and brilliancy of the ocean’s skin

2001-2032.scene_title: Ahab's Reflection and Dialogue with Starbuck and Stubb
2001-2032.description: Ahab reflects on the soothing scenes of the ocean, which temporarily affect him. Meanwhile, Starbuck and Stubb express their feelings towards the sea and their experiences, with Stubb declaring his jolly nature.
2001-2032.dialog_summary: Starbuck murmurs about the unfathomable loveliness of the sea, choosing to believe in its beauty over its dangers. Stubb declares his jolly nature and history.

2001-2032.description: The Nantucket ship, the Bachelor, is described as being in a festive mood, having successfully filled with sperm oil and now celebrating among other ships before heading home.
text_phrases: long streamers of narrow red bunting
long lower jaw of the last whale

2033-2071.description: Ahab and the Parsee are on a boat at night, observing the surroundings and engaging in a deep conversation about fate and omens.
2033-2071.location: On a boat in the ocean
2033-2071.dialog_summary: Ahab and the Parsee discuss omens of death and fate, with Ahab questioning the inevitability of his own death and the Parsee providing cryptic assurances about Ahab's destiny.
text_phrases: Ahab and all his boat’s crew
Parsee; who crouching in the bow
sharks, that spectrally played round the whale
tapped the light cedar planks with their tails

2033-2071.description: Ahab takes his daily observation of the sun to determine his latitude, while the Parsee observes alongside him.
2033-2071.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2033-2071.dialog_summary: Ahab reflects on his position and questions the sun about his and Moby Dick's whereabouts, expressing frustration with the limitations of his navigational tools.
text_phrases: Ahab, seated in the bows of his high-hoisted boat
taking his wonted daily observation of the sun
Parsee was kneeling beneath him on the ship’s deck
eyeing the same sun with him

2033-2071.description: The Pequod faces a fierce typhoon, causing chaos and damage on the ship.
2033-2071.location: On the Pequod during a typhoon
2033-2071.dialog_summary: Starbuck and Stubb discuss the typhoon's impact and the inevitability of facing nature's wrath, with Stubb singing to keep his spirits up.
text_phrases: the Pequod was torn of her canvas
bare-poled was left to fight a Typhoon
sky and sea roared and split with the thunder

2072-2103.description: During a storm at sea, the crew of the Pequod experiences supernatural phenomena with flames appearing on the masts and the harpoon. Ahab and Starbuck engage in a tense dialogue about the fate of their voyage.
2072-2103.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2072-2103.dialog_summary: Starbuck warns Ahab about the ill fate of their voyage and suggests making a fair wind home. Ahab, however, is resolute in his pursuit of the White Whale, dismissing Starbuck's concerns and asserting his command over the crew.
text_phrases: Blast the boat! let it go!

2104-2132.description: Stubb and Flask discuss the difficulty of their task while securing the anchors on deck during a stormy night.
2104-2132.dialog_summary: Stubb and Flask talk about how hard it is to work when soaked and discuss the permanence of their task of securing the anchors, comparing it to tying a man's hands.

2104-2132.description: During a violent typhoon, the crew struggles with the ship's tiller and compasses, while the sails are managed to cope with the storm.
text_phrases: man at the Pequod’s jaw-bone tiller
shivered remnants of the jib and fore and main-top-sails

2104-2132.description: Starbuck contemplates the potential consequences of killing Captain Ahab to save the crew, while standing outside Ahab's cabin.
2104-2132.location: Outside Ahab's Cabin on the Pequod
2104-2132.dialog_summary: Starbuck internally debates the morality and consequences of potentially killing Ahab to prevent further danger.
text_phrases: musket that he pointed at me
loaded musket’s end against the door

2133-2175.description: Ahab stands before the binnacle, takes the bearing of the sun, and commands the ship's course to be changed after confirming the compass needles are inverted.
2133-2175.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2133-2175.dialog_summary: Ahab shouts orders to change the ship's course.

2133-2175.description: Ahab performs a demonstration of magnetizing a needle to show his control over the compass, using tools handed to him by Starbuck.
2133-2175.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2133-2175.dialog_summary: Ahab explains how he can make his own compass needle and demonstrates it to the crew.
text_phrases: Ahab knocked off the steel head of the lance
handed to the mate the long iron rod
horizontally suspended the sail-needle by its middle
Ahab, who had been intently watching

2133-2175.description: Ahab orders the crew to heave the log to check the ship's speed, despite the old line being worn out.
2133-2175.dialog_summary: Ahab orders the log to be heaved and discusses the condition of the line with the Manxman.
text_phrases: Ahab stood before him, and was lightly unwinding some thirty or forty turns

2176-2221.description: A sailor from the Pequod goes to his mast-head and falls into the sea, leading to his death. A life-buoy is dropped but fails to save him.
text_phrases: from his hammock to his mast-head
a falling phantom in the air

2176-2221.description: After the loss of a sailor and the life-buoy, Starbuck orders the carpenter to convert Queequeg's coffin into a new life-buoy.
2176-2221.dialog_summary: Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask discuss converting Queequeg's coffin into a life-buoy. The carpenter expresses his dissatisfaction with the task.
text_phrases: Pay over the same with pitch

2176-2221.description: Ahab confronts the carpenter about his work on the coffin turned life-buoy, discussing the philosophical implications of his work.
2176-2221.dialog_summary: Ahab questions the carpenter's practices and the transformation of the coffin into a life-buoy, leading to a philosophical discussion about life and death.
text_phrases: The coffin laid upon two line-tubs
string of twisted oakum slowly unwinding
Ahab comes slowly from the cabin-gangway

2176-2221.description: The Pequod encounters the ship Rachel, which brings news of a recent sighting of Moby Dick and a lost whale-boat.
2176-2221.dialog_summary: The captain of the Rachel communicates with Ahab about the sighting of Moby Dick and the missing whale-boat, leading to a tense exchange.
text_phrases: large ship, the Rachel, was descried
bearing directly down upon the Pequod

2222-2247.description: The stranger captain boards the Pequod to request Captain Ahab to join in the search for his missing son, who was lost at sea with a whale-boat's crew.
2222-2247.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2222-2247.dialog_summary: The stranger captain pleads with Ahab to charter the Pequod for 48 hours to search for his missing son. Ahab refuses the request despite the stranger's pleas.

2222-2247.description: Captain Ahab shows his unwavering focus and determination to continue the hunt for Moby Dick, rejecting any distractions or deviations from his goal.
2222-2247.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2222-2247.dialog_summary: Ahab decisively rejects the stranger captain's request and commands his crew to prepare the ship to sail as before, emphasizing his commitment to the hunt for Moby Dick.

2222-2247.description: The ship Rachel continues its desperate and chaotic search for the missing children, showing signs of distress and hopelessness.
Pip, left alone on the deck, reflects on his isolation and expresses his thoughts aloud, revealing his inner turmoil and longing for companionship.
2222-2247.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2222-2247.dialog_summary: Pip talks to himself about his loneliness and his desire to be part of something, reflecting on his role and expressing a mix of emotions towards Ahab and the crew.

2248-2282.description: Ahab eats his meals alone in the open air, reflecting on his life and his constant vigilance on deck.
text_phrases: He ate in the same open air

2248-2282.scene_title: Ahab and the Parsee's Silent Watch
2248-2282.description: Ahab and the Parsee stand watch on deck, mostly in silence, occasionally speaking only when necessary.
2248-2282.dialog_summary: Occasional necessary exchanges on unmomentous matters.

2248-2282.description: Ahab, perched aloft, commands his crew to be vigilant in spotting whales, reflecting his distrust and monomania.
2248-2282.dialog_summary: Ahab commands the crew to man the mast-heads and to be sharp in spotting anything.

2248-2282.description: Ahab personally prepares a lookout nest to ensure he is the first to spot the whale, showing his obsessive control.
2248-2282.dialog_summary: Ahab instructs Starbuck to take charge of the rope as he prepares to ascend for a better view.
text_phrases: rigged a nest of basketed bowlines
received the two ends of the downward-reeved rope

2283-2313.description: Captain Ahab reflects deeply on his obsession with Moby Dick, expressing his inner turmoil and resolve to continue the chase despite the pleas from Starbuck to return home. Ahab's internal conflict and determination are highlighted as he gazes into the sea, haunted by his thoughts.
2283-2313.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2283-2313.dialog_summary: Starbuck pleads with Ahab to return home to their families, but Ahab is resolute in his pursuit of Moby Dick, expressing his inner conflict and determination.
text_phrases: like a blighted fruit tree he shook
cast his last, cindered apple to the soil

2283-2313.description: The crew of the Pequod, led by Captain Ahab, begins the chase for Moby Dick. Ahab, from his perch, spots the whale and commands the crew to prepare for the hunt. The scene captures the excitement and urgency as the crew sets sails and readies the boats.
2283-2313.dialog_summary: Ahab spots Moby Dick and commands the crew to man the mast-heads and prepare the boats. The crew responds with readiness and anticipation.
text_phrases: Man the mast-heads! Call all hands!
There she blows! A hump like a snow-hill! It is Moby Dick!

2283-2313.description: The boats of the Pequod close in on Moby Dick in a serene sea. The scene is tense yet eerily calm as the whale glides through the water, surrounded by a ring of foam and followed by flocks of birds. The hunters are mesmerized by the whale's majestic presence.
2283-2313.dialog_summary: The crew silently observes Moby Dick's movements, with Ahab giving commands to approach the whale cautiously.
text_phrases: the white sea-fowls longingly lingered over the agitated pool
the grand god revealed himself, sounded, and went out of sight

2314-2341.description: Moby Dick attacks the boat by sliding his jaw beneath it, causing it to break in two. Ahab and the crew struggle to survive amidst the chaos.
text_phrases: shooting his pleated head lengthwise beneath the boat
whale obliquely lying on his back
bluish pearl-white of the inside of the jaw
White Whale now shook the slight cedar
elastic gunwales were springing in and out
whale dallied with the doomed craft
frail gunwales bent in, collapsed, and snapped
bit the craft completely in twain
locked themselves fast again in the sea
crew at the stern-wreck clinging to the gunwales

2314-2341.description: After the boat is destroyed, Ahab struggles in the water, shouting commands to the ship to continue pursuing Moby Dick.
2314-2341.dialog_summary: Ahab shouts commands to continue the chase after Moby Dick and to drive him off.
text_phrases: Ahab in the water hailed her
chancing to rise on a towering crest

2314-2341.description: Ahab reflects on the wrecked boat and commands his crew as they prepare to continue the chase against Moby Dick.
2314-2341.dialog_summary: Ahab discusses the safety of the harpoon and the status of the crew, then commands to set the sail and continue the chase.
text_phrases: Ahab walking beneath his slouched hat
Stubb advanced and eyeing the wreck exclaimed
Ahab commanded them to lift him to his perch

2342-2365.description: At daybreak, the three mast-heads of the ship are manned anew, signaling the start of a new day of whaling.
2342-2365.dialog_summary: Ahab asks if the whale is visible, but receives a negative response.

2342-2365.description: Captain Ahab commands the crew to make sail and expresses urgency as he believes the whale is moving faster than anticipated.
2342-2365.dialog_summary: Ahab orders all hands to make sail and expresses regret over not keeping the top-gallant sails on overnight.
text_phrases: Turn up all hands and make sail

2342-2365.description: The ship speeds through the ocean in pursuit of Moby Dick, with the crew unified and driven by Captain Ahab's relentless determination.
2342-2365.dialog_summary: The crew spots Moby Dick and Ahab motivates them to capture the whale.
text_phrases: Moby Dick bodily burst into view

2342-2365.description: In a dramatic confrontation, Moby Dick attacks the boats, leading to chaos and destruction as the crew struggles to survive.
2342-2365.dialog_summary: Ahab commands the crew during the attack, and Moby Dick fiercely retaliates, causing havoc.
text_phrases: Moby Dick turned and was now coming for the three crews
Caught and twisted—corkscrewed in the mazes of the line

2366-2401.description: The ship rescues Ahab and others from the sea, picking up floating mariners and equipment. Ahab is found clinging to a broken part of his boat, and is helped onto the deck where he leans on Starbuck for support.
2366-2401.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2366-2401.dialog_summary: Ahab acknowledges the comfort of leaning on someone, Starbuck and others express concern for Ahab's injuries, and Ahab dismisses the severity of his condition.
text_phrases: Ahab was now found grimly clinging to his boat’s broken half
half-hung upon the shoulder of Starbuck
His ivory leg had been snapped off

2366-2401.description: Ahab, despite his injury, commands the crew to prepare for the next encounter with Moby Dick. He reflects on his unbreakable resolve and the inevitability of his confrontation with the whale.
2366-2401.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2366-2401.dialog_summary: Ahab orders the crew to prepare the ship and expresses his determination to pursue Moby Dick, despite the protests from Starbuck who sees the pursuit as madness.

2402-2436.scene_title: Ahab's Descent and the Lowering of Boats
2402-2436.description: Ahab is lowered to the deck and then gives the order to lower the boats. He pauses the descent momentarily to speak with Starbuck.
2402-2436.location: On the deck of the Pequod
2402-2436.dialog_summary: Ahab and Starbuck discuss the perilous nature of their voyage and the ominous fate that might await them, with Ahab expressing a feeling of aged weariness and impending doom.
text_phrases: steadily lowered through the cloven blue air to the deck
held one of the tackle-ropes on deck

2402-2436.description: As Ahab's boat is lowered and moves away from the Pequod, it is followed and attacked by sharks, snapping at the oars.
2402-2436.dialog_summary: A voice from the cabin warns Ahab of the sharks, but Ahab, consumed by his own thoughts and commands, ignores the warning.
text_phrases: the boat was pulling round close under the stern
sharks, seemingly rising from out the dark waters
maliciously snapped at the blades of the oars

2402-2436.description: Moby Dick emerges powerfully from the water, causing chaos among Ahab's crew and the boats.
2402-2436.dialog_summary: Ahab commands his crew to drive in their nails and pursue Moby Dick aggressively, despite the whale's powerful resistance and the dangerous presence of sharks.
text_phrases: waters around them slowly swelled in broad circles
a vast form shot lengthwise, but obliquely from the sea
the boats darted forward to the attack

2437-2456.scene_title: Ahab's Desperation and the Whale's Attack
2437-2456.description: Captain Ahab, in a desperate attempt to confront the whale, gives orders to his crew as the whale attacks the ship, causing chaos and destruction.
2437-2456.location: On the ocean, aboard the Pequod
2437-2456.dialog_summary: Ahab commands his crew to maneuver the ship to confront the whale, expressing his determination and despair. The crew reacts to the imminent danger and destruction caused by the whale.
text_phrases: Ahab staggered; his hand smote his forehead
The whale! The ship! cried the cringing oarsmen
Oars! oars! Slope downwards to thy depths, O sea
the before whale-smitten bow-ends of two planks burst through
Tashtego’s mast-head hammer remained suspended in his hand
the red flag, half-wrapping him as with a plaid
Starbuck and Stubb, standing upon the bowsprit beneath
Up helm, up helm! Oh, all ye sweet powers of air
the jaw! the jaw! Is this the end of all my bursting prayers?
Stand not by me, but stand under me, whoever you are that will now help Stubb
I grin at thee, thou grinning whale!
Cherries? I only wish that we were where they grow
the great shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years ago
